text: Okay, in which mode do you want to slice the model?
Let's start slicing! How high should the layers be?
How much infill do you want?
How much infill do you want?

To save material and lower the printing time, 3D printed objects are often not solid but have so called infill. You can select different patterns and fill rate. A higher fill rate increases the stability but also the printing time.
Okay, I will slice your model now. This might take a few seconds. Please stand by.
You can do the slicing with a slicing software on your PC or you can send me your model and I will slice it for you.

After the slicing process, the resulting machine code (gcode) file needs to be uploaded to the printer. If you sliced your model on your own, you can send the file to me and I upload it for you. Afterwards, I can start the print for you.
Depending on the object size and the slicing parameter the print can take several hours.
Normally, your print is ready to use after the printing process is finished. In some cases you need to do some post-processing like removing the support structures.
This was a short overview of the 3D printing workflow. What can i do for you next?

14.text: Slicing completed. Do you want to print it now?
